awd_abstract_narration:
Autonomous aerial vehicles (AAVs) including drones can solve societal grand challenges such as rapid delivery of medicine and wildfire protection in a completely new way. However, a major technical challenge remains: Today’s AAVs lack the artificial intelligence (AI) needed to safely operate in real-world urban air mobility environments. In such environments, AAVs operate in proximity of urban infrastructures (e.g. buildings), at low altitude, without much regulatory oversight, and under unpredictable conditions such as unexpected weather change or additional vehicles in the field. 

This 2-day workshop will bring together researchers working in academia, industry labs, and governmental agencies to discuss and refine uses cases and capabilities that are key elements of a research infrastructure designed to support the rapid evolution of advanced air autonomy algorithms and systems.  Such an infrastructure is envisioned to enable rapid integration and testing of research community components using a cyber and physical infrastructure that can support both in-person and remote operation. An initial implementation of an AAV research infrastructure is AirTonomy located at Purdue University. The workshop will invite a diverse group of individuals including potential users from academia, representatives of industry partners as well as national, state, and regional governments. Through pre-conference activities and in-person breakout sessions, the workshop participants will identify:  1) research use cases, 2) technical requirements of a large-scale research infrastructure, and 3) concepts for sustainability. After the workshop, a report will be published online, and a task force assembling a lead user community will assist with the finalization of research infrastructure requirements and design.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
The AIrTonomy Workshop, hosted September 11-12, 2024, brought a variety of experts together to develop a plan to implement a new experimental infrastructure, called AIrTonomy, intended to support research that demonstrates the safety of artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning (ML) systems for autonomous drones – also called autonomous aerial vehicles (AAVs). The workshop was guided by AIrTonomy’s vision to form a new aerial autonomy research community by offering researchers from various disciplines a unique way to perform physical experiments remotely. 

Figure 1: AIrTonomy Vision



In the activities held before, during and after the workshop, potential users and other key stakeholders were able to 1) learn the details of the existing and anticipated components of the AIrTonomy cyber-physical infrastructure; 2) develop research use cases; 3) network with one another to build a community of potential lead users; and 4) plan AIrTonomy’s sustainability using multiple forms of participation.

Interactive demonstrations showcased the scope of the existing and planned physical facilities and how they could be used remotely via the web. These facilities make up the Purdue Uncrewed Proving ground (PUP), a 15-mile triangular corridor that encompasses four indoor and outdoor labs for testing AAVs, a diverse fleet of small and large AAV, and ground systems for advanced communication and sensing (e.g. radars, cameras) to validate reliably operations of AAVs beyond the visual line of sight (BVLOS). Demonstrations held at the augmented aviation lab (AAL) illustrated how research could improve collaboration between humans and remotely flying drones using real-time sensing and brain-computer-interfaces. An autonomous taxing demonstration featured the motion capture capabilities of PURT, the largest indoor AAV testing facility in the US, for extremely accurate testing of new navigation systems. Outdoor demonstrations at Purdue’s digital forestry drone lab at Martell forest, the location of the Purdue Urban Canyon Lab (PUC) to be built in 2025, showcased how researchers could design novel systems that  transform AAV-enabled sensing and navigation at scale, even under constraints (e.g. when GPS signals degrade). Demonstrations also included an autonomous BVLOS mission of a large 31-feet wingspan drone remotely at an airfield, highlighting the benefits of the Earhart Airfield, a AAV airport to be opened in 2025. 

Complementary to such demonstrations, researchers contributed more than 30 use cases and shared infrastructure needs and requirements through lightning talks, poster sessions, panel discussions and a  survey. Expert panels discussed sustainability measures to ensure AIrTonomy’s ability to provide continuous access to researchers — with a goal to support about 300 short physical experiments (flights) indoors and outdoors, and 400 digital experiments a month (e.g. “virtual” flights using simulations). 

Intellectual merit: The workshop produced intellectual merits via insightful lightning talks, poster presentations, panel discussions, and community building. Participants shared research use cases and detailed infrastructure requirements related to AAV research on: 1) perception and navigation, 2) remote sensing, 3) human-autonomy teaming and remote operations, 4) cybersecurity and 5) digital twins.  Participants articulated a clear need for the integrated, remote use of all facilities within PUP and its capacity to support novel remote experimentation and easy transition back and forth between simulations to complex, real-world experiments. These complexities include operating BVLOS, under communication constraints (e.g. loss of GPS signal), with the need to realize safe interaction between remotely located humans and AAVs.  The workshop’s outcome document AIrTonomy’s capacity to 1) foster scientific progress by broadening access to high-quality ground truth data at a low cost; 2) increase scientific reproducibility through access to data, AI/ML models, and high-fidelity digital models of a physical system (also referred to as digital twins), 3) expand experimental capabilities using high-fidelity digital twin simulations across various conditions, 4) foster convergence and the integration of data-driven ML modeling and formal theory-based approaches. 

Broader impacts: The workshop made immediate broader impacts by increasing the awareness of the challenges inherent in operating autonomous aerial systems, and the research tools being used to overcome those challenges through AI and machine learning. Our workshop reached US citizens primarily on LinkedIn, YouTube and through opt-in email marketing. AIrTonomy engaged more than 4,300 individuals via LinkedIn through high quality multi-media content. Webinars and other videos introducing AIrTonomy concepts earned more than 500 views on YouTube. The workshop also directly involved underrepresented communities in its demonstrations and poster sessions.The organizing team also prepared an online information suite and report, to encourage a community of aerial autonomy scientists to interactively explore research use cases. This report includes high-quality demonstration videos, paper abstracts, posters, and additional references, showcasing how AIrTonomy will make significant national impacts in enhanced public safety (e.g., prevention of cyberattacks), improved environmental monitoring (e.g., wildlife, forest health, pollution), and workforce development. Participating industry representatives confirmed how experimentation with AIrTonomy can accelerate AAVs’ economic impact in the near future. 

 

 

 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 01/23/2025
Modified by: Sabine Brunswicker

Demonstrations also included an autonomous BVLOS mission of a large 31-feet wingspan drone remotely at an airfield, highlighting the benefits of the Earhart Airfield, a AAV airport to be opened in 2025.
